comment.body:
https://wix.github.io/Detox/docs/next/articles/design-principles

> Detox synchronizes with your app’s activity — By being aware of what your app is doing and synchronizing with it, Detox times its actions, by default, to run only when your app is idle, meaning it has determined that your app has finished its work, such as animations, network requests, React Native load, etc. You can further read on this [here](https://wix.github.io/Detox/docs/next/troubleshooting/synchronization)

This is not a recommended way to write your tests. After you pass your login screen which is not a React Native component (per what you say), try to enable the synchronization: `await device.enableSynchronization()`.

Running in an unsynchronized state will destabilize your tests - they will pass sometimes, sometimes not. Using `waitFor(...).toBeVisible().withTimeout(...)` API will help, but this is a resort, not the default way of writing tests.

As for why – Detox doesn't support well non-React Native apps, even though they're partial. My team mates don't have dedicated time to look into these issues, and people from the community are not willing to contribute there as well, so we live the way we live until today. 😞 

I'm glad that the workaround helped though. 🤷‍♂️ 🙂

issue.title: Add an option to disable synchronization on launchApp
issue.body:
### Describe your idea

Issues with idling resources timing out right upon the app launch cannot be solved via calling `device.disableSynchronization()`, because `await device.launchApp()` fails with a timeout error.

I suggest adding an option to `launchApp` where we'd disable synchronization right after the native DetoxManager connects to DetoxServer.

This issue is not familiar to me. We have [issues with native and brownfield apps](https://github.com/wix/Detox/issues/2543), but yours looks different. Hm, maybe you could try to [device.disableSynchronization()](https://wix.github.io/Detox/docs/next/api/device/#devicedisablesynchronization) for this specific screen?

That would look a bit horrible but as a proof of concept it could work:

```js
await Promise.race([
  device.launchApp({ newInstance: true }),
  sleep(10000).then(() => device.disableSynchronization()),
]);
```

where `sleep = (ms) => new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));`.
